Award.AwardTitle: Piping In(Out) of High Computer Science Curricula: Magnet School Lenses and Influencing Factors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Piping In(Out) of High School Computer Science Curricula: Magnet School Lenses and Influencing Factors addresses the relationship between the availability of computer science courses in high school and equitable access to those courses. On the heels of the CSforAll initiative, K-12 school districts across the country are developing an infrastructure to design and deliver rigorous CS education for the nearly 50,000,000 students in U.S. public schools. In places where CS courses already exist, students of color are often not enrolled, raising the distinction between availability and access.

Piping In(Out) of Computer Science examines the relationship between availability and access in two magnet schools in Wake County North Carolina. The schools have significant representation of students of color, but their enrollment in the CS courses is not representative of their population in the schools. Because the high schools are magnet, all students are high achievers and many of the extracurricular arguments for lack of enrollment for students of color in advanced technical courses do not hold. This study examines the school structures that affect equitable student engagement in computer science in schools that do not have the challenge of availability. As school districts around the country prepare for the implementation of CSforAll, Piping In(Out) of CS offers insights into equitable deployment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF Award# 1740141 

 

Project Title: Piping In(Out) of High Computer Science Curricula: Magnet School Lenses and Influencing Factors

Recipient Organization: North Carolina State University

Project/Grant Period: 07/15/2017 - 12/31/2019

PI: Kathy Gore (PI, Substitute Negotiator for Fay Cobb Payton)

This project explored the presence of computer science (CS) curricula availability at two well-sourced North Carolina magnet schools, barriers precluding female, African-American, Hispanic or Latinx, and Native American students from gaining access to and participation in current CS curricula, and the pathways (if any) to completion of the CS advanced placement examination. The pathway(s) to Advanced Placement CS has been met with well-documented barriers to Black, Hispanic/Latino, Native American and female high school students. While student data were collected from high schools which are often considered well-resourced, students of color enrollment in CS courses is not representative of the overall school population.  This project determined that clusters of courses can offer insights into student enrollment in CS.  These included pathways where 1) students completing STEM + ARTS (STEAM), 2) students completing STEAM + World Languages, 3) students completing Computer Application or Computer Technical Education curricula, and 4) students completing English, Math, Remedial, and Sciences with Remedial courses are notable in this cluster and do not appear in groups 1 through 3. In this cluster, students are less likely to participate in AP CS or the types of gateway courses to strengthen their likelihood of inclusion.

 

The project’s research also explored issues of availability of high school CS courses to students.  If schools are not offering CS, virtual availability does not equate to access given the socio-economic challenges associated with broadband in urban and rural areas. With existing demographic disparities in CS education, ecosystems that marry curricula clusters, inclusive approaches and policy are proposed to best address CS participation.

 

The issues of policy, course clusters and pathways led to examine undergraduate computer science (CS) graduation rates among six higher education institutions in North Carolina from 2007 to 2017.  Few Native American students completed CS degrees across these schools in the last decade.  While the number of males participating in CS is increasing, the number of females is not increasing at a similar rate. While the number of completed CS bachelor’s degrees appears to be increasing across the North Carolina institutions, it appears to only be increasing for one group: white males. At the majority of schools (with the exception of North Carolina A&T University, a historically black college and university), CS degrees were completed by white males. Specific details are provided in forthcoming and/or published works associated with this project.

 

The project has a number of broader impacts and outcomes. The CS challenge is influenced by (in)equitable broadening participation, local/state/national policy and the perceived prestige associated with school systems and higher education practices. Subject cluster enrollments can provide insights regarding students’ career interests (in part) and enable school administrators and policymakers to consider multiple pathways to CS. Computing application courses have significant enrollment while the intersection of CS/STEM-related courses and the Arts being evident. This could show CS + X (or X + CS) arrangements as pathways to computing.  Lastly, the use and appropriateness of national data sets to examine CS graduation trends can offer some preliminary analyses for how minority-serving institutions can and do enable inclusion and what issues continue to challenge “who is and gets to evenly participate” in computing.  The project’s website, changecomputerscience.org, provides a summary of research outcomes and conference/journal publications.
